pullRequest.body:
This PR drops support from several operations from the `linear_combination` tactic:
- multiplication of two hypotheses
- division by a hypothesis
- inversion of a hypothesis
- addition or subtraction of a constant and a hypothesis

The first three operations are removed in order to make `linear_combination` perform only genuinely linear operations; this makes the tactic more predictable and also allows for more flexibility in refactors/reimplementations. The last operation is removed because, after of the removal of the other three, it is redundant (adding a constant to both sides of an equation doesn't change the difference of the two sides).

The old operations are still available using the `congr(...)` term elaborator or using the legacy `linear_combination'` tactic.

A side effect that be seen in `Mathlib/AlgebraicGeometry/EllipticCurve/Weierstrass.lean` is that elaboration changes slightly; previously `‚Åª¬π` was one of the supported operations *on hypotheses*, so `‚Åª¬π` got handled differently *in constants* too.  In that example, previously the atom which got pre-elaborated was `C'.u`; now the atom which gets pre-elaborated is `C'.u‚Åª¬π`.

Discussion on [Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Narrowing.20the.20scope.20of.20.60linear_combination.60)

---

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

### PR summary [8dbd25e25c](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15899/commits/8dbd25e25c8a9ecee001f36be87eab08507214c6)

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.AlgebraicGeometry.EllipticCurve.Jacobian | 1253 | 1254 | +1 (+0.08%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
|<details><summary>4 files</summary> `Mathlib.AlgebraicGeometry.EllipticCurve.Group` `Mathlib.AlgebraicGeometry.EllipticCurve.DivisionPolynomial.Basic` `Mathlib.AlgebraicGeometry.EllipticCurve.Jacobian` `Mathlib.AlgebraicGeometry.EllipticCurve.DivisionPolynomial.Degree`</details>|1|

</details>

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`- c_add_pf`
`- c_div_pf`
`- c_sub_pf`
`- div_pf`
`- inv_pf`
`- mul_pf`
`- pf_add_c`
`- pf_sub_c`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
Please describe the change of scope in the commit message (e.g., by copy+pasting relevant paragraphs from the Zulip thread).
This is something that won't be settled until #16103 is decided about.
I believe the Zulip discussion reached consensus in favour of this change, so I will remove that tag.
Just to check: there is no docstring change here because the feature was never documented in the first place? Or was the docstring pre-emptively updated in a previous PR?

> Just to check: there is no docstring change here because the feature was never documented in the first place?

Right, the docstring dates from the Lean 3 tactic, whereas the features were added in the port.

> I think it would be reasonable if you updated the docstrings of `linear_combination` and `linear_combination'`:
>
> > `linear_combination'`: Note: There is also a similar tactic `linear_combination` (no prime); this version is provided for backward compatibility.
> 
> At least mention the difference implemented in this PR.

I have done this (98579c8d49852d5ae861b3f892635ecb1847e8a5).  Just flagging that I don't necessarily think that it is sustainable in the long term to continue to document the differences between the two: in the future I hope to extend the scope of `linear_combination` quite substantially.

Thank you heather for addressing the comments! I'm conviced now that this is a positive change overall, and I'm looking forward to see more changes to the new `linear_combination`

Maybe Eric can "maintainer merge" once happy :)

I think since @eric-wieser marked the last conversation as resolved, I can suggest

maintainer merge

Thanks for the PR!
üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by joneugster.
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10846535735/job/30099689055)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10846535735/job/30099688146)

I think it would be reasonable if you updated the docstrings of `linear_combination` and `linear_combination'`:

> `both`: If the `normalize` field of the configuration is set to false

I think this should be changed to using `(norm := skip)`, right? (that's not directly relevant here, but I tripped over it when looking at the one situation above you used `linear_combination'`)

> `linear_combination'`: Note: There is also a similar tactic `linear_combination` (no prime); this version is provided for backward compatibility.

At least mention the difference implemented in this PR.
Losing support for semirings feels like a bit of a shame; would it make sense to combine the syntaxes, but fallback to this approach internally if no ring can be found?

I really think the tactic is *improved* by removing this from the scope.  I laid out my thoughts here
https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Narrowing.20the.20scope.20of.20.60linear_combination.60/near/462845544
(and let's continue the discussion there rather than here), but for the record, let me write precisely what I think that scope should be:

`linear_combination` is a tactic which reduces problems of the form
```
h‚ÇÅ : a‚ÇÅ = b‚ÇÅ
h‚ÇÇ : a‚ÇÇ = b‚ÇÇ
h‚ÇÉ : a‚ÇÉ = b‚ÇÉ
‚ä¢ A = B
```
to the task of showing that 
```
(f a‚ÇÅ a‚ÇÇ a‚ÇÉ - f b‚ÇÅ b‚ÇÇ b‚ÇÉ) - (A - B)
```
equals zero (and then tries a standard normalization procedure to check that).  I believe the scope of the tactic should be limited to operations `f` for which this is the same thing as
```
f (a‚ÇÅ - b‚ÇÅ) (a‚ÇÇ - b‚ÇÇ) (a‚ÇÉ - b‚ÇÉ) - (A - B)
```
Namely, **‚Ñ§-linear** operations `f`.
I don't think that removing support for `Nat` makes the tactic better. I would prefer the tactic to swap LHS and RHS as needed to avoid `-`.
@urkud I'm not sure what you mean here -- as of #16103 Nat is supported natively (and `-` *means* swapping).  Can you say a bit more about your concern?
I wrote my comment before the description of the scope change was added. Please ignore it.
nit: I'd argue that if it were agnostic to them, this would be a warning not an error. Throwing an error doesn't sound agnostic to me!
OK, let me know if you have alternative wording that still accomplishes the goal of dropping this functionality!

Either
```suggestion
    | _ , _ => throwError "'linear_combination' does not support addition of constants as it would have no effect"
```
or
```suggestion
    | .proof p, .const _ | .const _, .proof p =>
      logWarning "'linear_combination' is agnostic to the addition of constants, so this has no effect"
      pure (.proof p)
```
where the second one allows users to ignore the warning just like they can a deprecation warning.
I like the second one and have implemented it.  Let's revisit this if needed when the other planned refactors come.
looks resolved to me
Can you add a test for this?

~~I have to say, debugging the example above I found this message not immensely helpful. Is it possible that the error message mentions the term it is upset about?~~

Let's say this is out-of-scope and can always be done later :)
I added tests, and I localized the error to the offending `*` or `/` symbol -- what do you think?

```suggestion
  have hx‚ÇÉ : (P x * Q z ^ 2) ^ 3 = (Q x * P z ^ 2) ^ 3 := by
    rw [hx]
  have hx‚ÇÇ : (P x * Q z ^ 2) ^ 2 = (Q x  * P z ^ 2) ^ 2 := by
    rw [hx]
  linear_combination (norm := (rw [negY]; ring1)) Q z ^ 6 * (equation_iff P).mp hP
    - P z ^ 6 * (equation_iff Q).mp hQ + hx‚ÇÉ + W'.a‚ÇÇ * P z ^ 2 * Q z ^ 2 * hx‚ÇÇ
    + (W'.a‚ÇÑ * P z ^ 4 * Q z ^ 4 - W'.a‚ÇÅ * P y * P z * Q z ^ 4) * hx
```

I assume this (and comment below) is how one is supposed to solve this now using `linear_combination`, isn't it?

The most direct translation would be to use the `congr(...)` term elaborator:
```lean
  linear_combination (norm := (rw [negY]; ring1)) Q z ^ 6 * (equation_iff P).mp hP
    - P z ^ 6 * (equation_iff Q).mp hQ + congr($hx ^ 3) + W'.a‚ÇÇ * P z ^ 2 * Q z ^ 2 * congr($hx ^ 2)
    + (W'.a‚ÇÑ * P z ^ 4 * Q z ^ 4 - W'.a‚ÇÅ * P y * P z * Q z ^ 4) * hx
```
But in general, a "nonlinear" linear combination has a code smell to me.  For example, I would find it more elegant to solve this example in this way (which `polyrith` produced for me), using a purely "linear" linear combination and avoiding the nonstandard discharger:
```lean
  rw [equation_iff, negY] at *
  linear_combination Q z ^ 6 * hP - P z ^ 6 * hQ
    + (Q z ^ 4 * P z ^ 4 * W'.a‚ÇÑ - P y * Q z ^ 4 * P z * W'.a‚ÇÅ 
      + Q z ^ 2 *  P z ^ 2 * (P z ^ 2 * Q x + Q z ^ 2 * P x) * W'.a‚ÇÇ 
      + (P z ^ 4 * Q x ^ 2 + Q z ^ 2 * P z ^ 2 * Q x * P x + Q z ^ 4 * P x ^ 2)) * hx
```

In any case, did you write these variants to check your understanding of the "story" of this PR, or are they intended as genuine suggested changes?  The approach I have taken on these two examples which are hit by the downgrade -- switching them over to `linear_combination'`, to serve as a record of the extent-of-use of the functionality which has been removed --  was requested by @digama0:
https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Narrowing.20the.20scope.20of.20.60linear_combination.60/near/465256620

Thanks for the explanation, your snippet is indeed much more elegant!

So my suggestion is to just replace these two uses of `linear_combination'` with the solution you just wrote out, since thats nicer than the original anyways.

But also, I think the PR can be merged regardless if you do that or not :)
If you don't mind either way, then let's go with the status quo, since Mario preferred it!

```suggestion
  have h‚ÇÇ : (P y ^ 2) ^ 2 = (P x ^ 3) ^ 2 := by
    rw [(equation_of_Z_eq_zero hPz).mp hP]
  linear_combination (norm :=
      (rw [negDblY, dblU_of_Z_eq_zero hPz, dblX_of_Z_eq_zero hP hPz, negY_of_Z_eq_zero hPz]; ring1))
    8 * h‚ÇÇ - 12 * P x ^ 3 * (equation_of_Z_eq_zero hPz).mp hP
```
Why did this end up changing?

I think I looked at this earlier and from top of my head:

Previously the tactic would parse the `\^-1` before the term `C.u` was parsed (and translate it into using one of the theorems that got removed) but now it's actually the normal term parser parsing the entire `C.u\^-1`.

Therefore, now it thinks the inverse should be taken in `R` instead of in `R\^x` without the coersion hint (which is btw also displayed in the goal). This seems like normal Lean behaviour so the coersion hints are in my opinion expected there.

Previously `‚Åª¬π` was one of the supported operations *on hypotheses*, so `‚Åª¬π` got handled differently *in constants* too: the atom which got pre-elaborated was `C'.u`.  Now the atom which gets pre-elaborated is `C'.u‚Åª¬π`.  (Though I don't actually see why it makes a difference here!)

Edit: sorry, I didn't see @joneugster's response when I replied!
Thanks, I've copied @hrmacbeth's version into the PR description.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - refactor: downgrade `linear_combination`
